Article Title: Ekman, who linked facial expressions to emotions, dies at 91
Article Text: Paul Ekman, a psychologist who linked thousands of facial expressions to the emotions they often subconsciously conveyed, and who used his research to advise FBI interrogators and screeners for the Transportation Security Administration as well as Hollywood animators, died Nov 17 at his home in San Francisco. He was 91.Ekman sought to add scientific exactitude to the human impulse to interpret how others feel through their facial expressions. He recorded 18 types of smiles, for example, distinguishing between a forced smile and a spontaneous one; a genuine smile, he discovered, crinkles the orbicularis oculi muscle - that is, it creates crow's feet around the eyes.Sometimes described as the world's most famous face reader, Ekman was influential in reshaping the way facial expressions were understood - as the product of evolution rather than environment - and his findings crossed over to popular culture.As a young researcher in the late 1960s, Ekman changed the scientific consensus on facial expressions. In the postwar era, the conventional wisdom of eminent anthropologists like Margaret Mead was that human facial expressions were learned and that they varied across cultures. Ekman believed otherwise. He showed photographs of people making faces expressing 30 different emotions - including anger, joy and fear - to subjects in the United States, Japan and South America.Across cultures, the study's participants linked the expressions they were shown with the same emotions.He then travelled to Papua New Guinea with a colleague, Wallace V Friesen, and showed the same pictures to some 300 Indigenous people who had no exposure to modern media and could not have learned to interpret faces that way. These subjects also connected the expressions to the same emotions."There is a pan-cultural element in facial expressions of emotion," Ekman wrote in a paper in 1970 on returning to the United States.
Article Summary: Paul Ekman, a psychologist who linked thousands of facial expressions to the emotions they often subconsciously conveyed, died Nov 17 at his home in San Francisco. Ekman was influential in reshaping the way facial expressions were understood. He recorded 18 types of smiles, for example, distinguishing between a forced smile and a spontaneous one.

Article Title: Inside the deal-making power of the F-35: A weapon, a network, a strategic lock-in
Article Text:
Israel Or Saudi, Who Has F-35 Edge? Mid-East Air Power Balance Decoded; Game-Changer Or Paper Tiger?

The Israel - Saudi Arabia dynamics





Let's dive deeper into what this beast really is :-





What defines a

fifth-generation fighter jet

? A full breakdown

.

How Washington uses fighter jets as diplomacy and leverage

Why the Saudi F-35 deal raises concerns: The China-Pakistan angle

The global map of fifth-generation fighter jets: Who has what

The United States‚Äô F-35 ‚Äî dominant in number & deployment

China‚Äôs J-20 ‚Äî the leading non-Western competitor

Russia‚Äôs Su-57 ‚Äî operational, but limited in scale & integration

How the US retains control through software, sanctions and upgrade restrictions

Why the US limits updates and weapons access even for its allies

Why the F-35 stands beyond Russian fifth-gen capability

Inside the satellite-driven combat network that makes the F-35 nearly invisible





NEW DELHI: The "Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II" is not just another fighter jet ‚Äî it is a geopolitical instrument, a technological ecosystem and the most widely exported fifth-generation aircraft ever produced. No other defence platform in the modern era has reshaped alliances, altered regional balances of power, or influenced international diplomacy the way the F-35 has. From Europe to West Asia, from the Indo-Pacific to Nato‚Äôs forward edge, the aircraft has become a tool through which Washington strengthens partnerships, discourages adversaries, builds influence and enforces compliance.The F-35 represents more than stealth ‚Äî it represents networked warfare, real-time intelligence fusion and precision strike capability that allows pilots to ‚Äúsee first, fire first and disappear.‚Äù A US analyst once summarised the aircraft in one sentence: The F-35 is what happens when a jet becomes a computer that kills.Its strategic dominance is the reason states compete to buy it ‚Äî and also why Washington tightly controls who receives it, at what configuration, when upgrades are released, and what internal code becomes accessible. The F-35 is both a fighter and a foreign-policy lever.As the United States tries to rebalance the Middle East through fighter jet diplomacy and trade, a proposed sale of its most advanced combat aircraft, the F-35, to Saudi Arabia has put Israel firmly at the centre of the debate.The potential deal, discussed during Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman‚Äôs visit to the White House and his talks with US President Donald Trump, envisages Riyadh joining the exclusive club of F-35 operators. But officials and reports say the Saudi jets, if the sale goes through, will be delivered in a less advanced configuration than those flown by Israel, in line with Washington‚Äôs long-standing commitment to preserve Israel‚Äôs qualitative military edge in the region.According to Reuters, US officials have indicated that the F-35s planned for Saudi Arabia will lack some of the superior features installed on Israel‚Äôs fleet, including advanced weapons systems and electronic warfare equipment. Israel, which has been operating the F-35 for roughly eight years, enjoys unique permissions to modify its aircraft, integrating its own weapons and adding radar-jamming and other upgrades without seeking fresh US approval. Still, the Israeli Air Force has opposed the proposed Saudi sale, warning in a position paper to political leaders that it could erode Israel‚Äôs air superiority in the region, The Times of Israel reported. Defence experts also note that even if Saudi Arabia gets the jets, it is unlikely to receive the AIM-260 Joint Advanced Tactical Missile, the next-generation air-to-air weapon being developed for fifth-generation platforms, as Douglas Birkey of the Mitchell Institute for Aerospace Studies has pointed out.A fifth-generation fighter jet is not simply a more modern aircraft ‚Äî it is a leap in how air warfare is fought, sensed, processed and won. Fourth-generation jets like the F-16, Su-30 or Mirage 2000 are machines of speed, thrust and manoeuvre, designed for visual-range engagements with radar as their primary sensor. Fifth-generation fighters are not built merely to fight ‚Äî they are built to detect, decide and destroy without ever being seen.In military terms, a fifth-generation fighter is defined by a convergence of technologies rather than a single capability. The first is stealth. These aircraft are engineered to minimise radar cross-section through angled geometry, radar-absorbent composites, internal weapons bays that eliminate external drag signatures, and infrared suppression to reduce heat signature. Unlike earlier fighters, which radiate powerfully when scanning for threats, fifth-generation jets can enter heavily defended airspace without announcing themselves.The second defining feature is sensor fusion. A modern fifth-generation aircraft does not feed a pilot separate streams of radar, infrared, targeting pod and electronic surveillance data. Instead, onboard computers merge all sensor inputs ‚Äî from the aircraft itself and from external assets such as AWACS, satellites or friendly fighters ‚Äî into one single tactical picture. Pilots no longer interpret dials; they see the entire battlespace as if viewed from above.The third layer is network-centric warfare. Fifth-generation fighters are not lone hunters. They are nodes in a digital combat mesh, sharing encrypted data silently through low-probability-intercept links. An enemy aircraft detected by one jet can be targeted by another. A missile launched by a ground battery can be guided by the data uplink of an aircraft hundreds of kilometres away. This ability to fight as a distributed swarm rather than as isolated aircraft fundamentally reshapes air power.Advanced avionics and electronic warfare complete the definition. A fifth-generation jet can jam enemy radars, spoof missile seekers, absorb electromagnetic signals for tracking, and identify threats passively without using its own radar. And unlike legacy platforms, which improve only with major hardware refits, fifth-generation jets evolve through software. Each system upgrade can expand detection range, add weapons integration, enhance stealth performance, and reconfigure threat libraries without redesigning the airframe.True fifth-generation capability, therefore, is not just stealth or thrust ‚Äî it is stealth + fusion + networking + EW dominance + software-driven evolution. Only a few nations have achieved it at scale. The United States leads with the F-22 and F-35, China fields the J-20, and Russia‚Äôs Su-57 is still maturing. Others, from Japan and South Korea to India and Europe, are now racing toward sixth-generation development.For United States, selling a fighter jet ‚Äî especially one as tightly controlled and technologically dense as the F-35 ‚Äî is never just an arms deal. It is foreign policy with wings. Fighter exports form the backbone of long-term military partnerships, binding nations to American logistics chains, software ecosystems, training infrastructure and, by extension, strategic alignment. Unlike traditional defence sales that end at delivery, fifth-generation platforms create decades-long dependence through updates, maintenance and weapons integration cycles. In practice, a country purchasing an American fighter is not just buying an aircraft ‚Äî it is entering a relationship.Washington has mastered this form of influence. Nations that operate US platforms rely on American training academies, spare-parts pipelines, engine overhaul depots, weapons testing facilities and encrypted mission-data updates. Every missile added, every software patch authorised, every radar mode unlocked passes through Washington. This system of controlled access means jets double as diplomatic leverage ‚Äî a partner aligned with US interests receives faster upgrades, deeper integration, and next-generation weapons; one that defies US strategic preferences risks delays, sanctions or removal from programmes entirely.Turkey stands as a pivotal example. Once a full partner in the F-35 programme, it was expelled after purchasing Russia‚Äôs S-400 missile system, losing aircraft access, industrial participation and billions in future revenue. The message was clear: ownership is conditional, and alignment is monitored continuously. In West Asia, the dynamic is even sharper. While Israel receives the most advanced F-35 variant with unrestricted modification rights, Saudi Arabia and the UAE face conditional pathways shaped by politics, security guarantees and trust evaluations. The aircraft has become a reward in geopolitical negotiation ‚Äî allocated not just by purchase capacity, but by reliability as an ally.Washington also uses fighter jet access to shape regional balance. When Russia grows more assertive in Europe, Nato states receive accelerated F-35 deliveries. When China expands its footprint in the Pacific, Japan, South Korea and Australia acquire larger fleets. Where deterrence is needed, jets are not merely sold ‚Äî they are stationed, forward-deployed and network-integrated. Air power becomes a diplomatic signal: a squadron represents intent; a fleet represents alignment.The possible sale of American F-35 fighter jets to Saudi Arabia has triggered concern within US defence circles, mainly over fears that sensitive technology could slip into the hands of China or Pakistan.A New York Times report, citing a Defense Intelligence Agency brief, outlined concerns that China could eventually access stealth-signature, electronic warfare and radar-absorption modelling if Saudi Arabia imported F-35s into an environment where Chinese contractors provide network infrastructure or defence systems integration. Fifth-generation technology is not just metal and avionics ‚Äî it is algorithms, mission-data files, sensor-fusion logic, heat-signature shaping and software-defined radar behaviour. Modern aircraft intelligence can be compromised by observing emissions, not stealing hardware.The risk is amplified by how the F-35 works. Its stealth coating chemistry, radar-cross-section shaping and EW system profiles are jealously guarded secrets. Even partial exposure ‚Äî radar testing from different angles, heat-signature mapping during take-off, or electromagnetic sniffing during exercises ‚Äî could help adversaries develop counter-stealth solutions. A single compromised maintenance facility, a breached digital-link terminal or a shared runway environment can generate exploitable telemetry.Pakistan emerges as a secondary risk vector. Though Saudi Arabia would not directly transfer Western equipment to Islamabad, support personnel, training officers, or data exposure through joint exercises could indirectly benefit Pakistan‚Äôs China-aligned aviation programmes, including development of the J-20 and future stealth derivatives. Washington‚Äôs caution reflects precedent: Pakistan received F-16s under strict conditions, and even those platforms faced upgrade restrictions over decade-long concerns of technology diversion to China.This is why, even if Riyadh eventually receives the aircraft, officials quoted by Reuters and defence analysts note the jets would almost certainly be a restricted configuration ‚Äî without Israel-level electronic warfare autonomy, without independent modification rights, and likely without access to the AIM-260 JATM, the most sensitive next-generation air-combat missile. The architecture would be export-sanitised because leakage is difficult to reverse.US officials say the sale is still under review, and any final agreement will require a detailed security assessment. For now, Washington is weighing two priorities ‚Äî strengthening ties with Saudi Arabia, and ensuring the F-35‚Äôs sensitive technology does not reach rival powers.Fifth-generation fighters remain the rarest and most strategically valuable aircraft in the world ‚Äî and today, only a handful of nations operate them at scale. At the centre of this landscape is the American F-35, the only fifth-gen platform deployed across multiple continents, services and alliances.The United States leads the field, operating all three variants ‚Äî Air Force (F-35A), Marine Corps STOVL (F-35B) and Navy carrier-based (F-35C). The jet is now the backbone of Western air power and has been adopted or ordered across Europe, including by the United Kingdom, Italy, Norway, Denmark, the Netherlands and Finland. In the Indo-Pacific, Japan, South Korea and Australia have emerged as major F-35 operators, a deployment pattern closely aligned with Washington‚Äôs broader strategy to deter Chinese expansion.Israel became the first operator in West Asia and remains the only regional user to have deployed the F-35 in real combat missions, benefiting from exceptional access, early delivery and custom integration rights.Outside the US-led ecosystem, fifth-generation efforts are smaller and far more limited. China‚Äôs J-20 is the most advanced non-Western platform currently in service, designed primarily for long-range interception and air-superiority missions, with an eye on US surveillance aircraft and refuelling tankers in the Pacific. Beijing is also developing a second stealth jet ‚Äî the FC-31/J-35 ‚Äî expected to serve aboard future carrier groups.Russia fields the Su-57, but in small numbers, constrained by sanctions, funding pressures and production inefficiencies. While technologically capable in manoeuvrability and close-combat performance, the fleet remains too small to shift global balance in the near term.A few nations are developing future systems ‚Äî Japan‚Äôs F-X, the UK-Italy-Japan Tempest programme, Europe‚Äôs FCAS, and India‚Äôs AMCA ‚Äî yet none have reached operational maturity.As of now, the global fifth-generation landscape is essentially a three-pole arena:Until the next generation arrives, the F-35 remains the benchmark ‚Äî and the only stealth fighter shaping alliances across the world.One of the least visible but most powerful aspects of the F-35 programme is software control. Modern aircraft are software-defined machines. Their flight characteristics, radar modes, electronic warfare responses, weapons employment envelopes and threat libraries are all governed by lines of code. In previous generations, once an aircraft was exported, the buyer had considerable freedom to alter and integrate systems. The F-16 could be rewired and retrofitted domestically, and several countries built their own versions or added indigenous weapons.The F-35 is different. Core mission software, electronic warfare libraries, and threat-identification files are not transferred outright; they are licensed and regularly updated via US-approved channels. This means that Washington retains decisive influence over how far and how fast an F-35 operator can expand its capabilities. Upgrades can be slowed, withheld or tailored. Certain weapons or radar modes can be restricted. In extreme cases, the flow of support and spare parts can be cut altogether.Turkey‚Äôs experience offers a case study. After Ankara took delivery of Russia‚Äôs S-400 air defence system, the US government removed Turkey from the F-35 consortium, halted planned deliveries and shifted production work away from Turkish firms. In effect, the programme was used not only as a supply contract but as an instrument of sanction. For potential buyers such as Saudi Arabia or the UAE, the message is clear: access to the F-35 comes with expectations about broader strategic alignment, and divergence carries costs.Even among close partners, Washington carefully calibrates the level of capability it provides through the F-35. This is partly driven by the legal requirement to maintain Israel‚Äôs qualitative military edge in West Asia, and partly by a broader desire to prevent sensitive technology from falling into hostile hands or being reverse-engineered.In practice, this means that not all F-35 operators receive the same radar modes, electronic warfare options or weapons integration at the same time. Highly sensitive systems such as next-generation air-to-air missiles, advanced stand-off weapons and cutting-edge jamming suites may be offered only to a small subset of trusted allies, or delayed until Washington is confident that the regional balance will not be destabilised.There is also a structural interest in maintaining dependence. If every country had identical capabilities and full control over their F-35 software environment, the leverage that comes from upgrade control would diminish. For the United States, the ability to say ‚Äúnot yet‚Äù or ‚Äúnot this particular weapon‚Äù is part of how it shapes the behaviour of even close partners. This sometimes generates friction: air forces that see themselves as front-line contributors to coalition operations may resent being held back from the latest configurations. But from Washington‚Äôs perspective, the risks of over-sharing are high, particularly in a world where cyber espionage and covert technical cooperation blur the lines of trust.Comparisons between the F-35 and Russia‚Äôs Su-57 are often framed in symbolic terms: two rival fifth-generation fighters, representing two competing geopolitical blocs. Yet in practical terms, the two aircraft inhabit different worlds.The F-35 is more numerous by an order of magnitude. Global F-35 deliveries have crossed the four-figure mark and are still rising, with long-term projections of more than 3,000 aircraft over the life of the programme. The Su-57, by contrast, is present only in small numbers, with production hampered by sanctions, industrial constraints and budgetary pressures. This matters because air power, especially in prolonged conflicts, depends not just on the quality of individual aircraft but on the ability to sustain and replace losses.Stealth and networking also separate the two platforms. The Su-57 incorporates stealth features, but open-source assessments suggest that its radar cross-section reduction is inferior to Western designs, particularly from the rear and at certain frequencies. Coating durability, nozzle shaping and panel fit all contribute. The F-35, drawing on decades of US work on the F-117, B-2 and F-22, is widely assessed to have a lower signature and more mature low-observable maintenance regime.More fundamentally, the F-35 is integrated into a wider Western network of satellites, ground stations, AWACS and datalinked assets. The Su-57 operates primarily within Russia‚Äôs own air defence and command infrastructure, which does not have the same global reach or the same level of coalition interoperability. In a beyond-visual-range engagement, the ability of a fighter to draw on offboard sensors can be as important as its onboard performance. On that metric, the F-35‚Äôs ecosystem gives it a significant advantage.If stealth is the body of the F-35‚Äôs advantage, the satellite-networked combat system that surrounds it is the mind. The jet is deeply integrated into secure satellite communication networks that relay encrypted tactical information from across a theatre and beyond. These links allow the F-35 to receive target coordinates and threat data from sources hundreds or even thousands of kilometres away, including space-based sensors, maritime platforms and airborne early warning aircraft.Because it can rely on this stream of external information, the F-35 does not need to use its own radar aggressively to build a picture of the battlespace. Its passive sensors ‚Äî infrared cameras, electronic support measures and distributed aperture systems ‚Äî detect emissions from enemy radars, missiles and aircraft. The mission computer fuses these inputs with offboard data, presenting the pilot with a coherent, real-time picture. In a radar-saturated environment such as the Taiwan Strait or Eastern Europe, this allows the F-35 to remain electronically quiet while still operating with full awareness.This networked approach changes how air campaigns are planned. A formation of F-35s can act as forward sensors for other aircraft or missile systems, passing back targeting data without ever exposing themselves. They can launch weapons cued by remote sources or guide munitions fired by other platforms. Rather than thinking of each jet as a discrete combatant, planners increasingly view them as nodes in a mesh network.For countries that buy the F-35, entry into this network is as significant as acquisition of the aircraft itself. For countries that are denied access, the absence is equally stark. That is why the programme has become not simply a procurement issue but a marker of strategic orientation. It defines who is inside the most advanced Western airpower ecosystem ‚Äî and who remains outside, watching from a different sky.
Article Summary: The F-35 represents networked warfare, real-time intelligence fusion and precision strike capability. No other defence platform in the modern era has reshaped alliances, altered regional balances of power, or influenced international diplomacy the way the F- 35 has. Israel has opposed the proposed Saudi sale, warning that it could erode Israel‚Äôs air superiority in the region.

Difference between a Nominee and a Legal heir

Aspect Nominee Legal Heir Role Custodian Owner Transfer of Assets Can be done without any legal formalities. Requires testamentary documents for proof of ownership. When individuals open bank accounts, invest in mutual funds, or buy insurance, they are often asked to name a nominee.However, many people mistakenly assume that the nominee automatically inherits the assets. In reality, the nominee is not always the final recipient ‚Äî the ownership rights belong to the legal heir, reported ET.Understanding the distinction between these two is essential to ensure that your wealth is passed on to the intended beneficiaries.A nominee acts as a temporary custodian of the deceased person‚Äôs assets.The nominee‚Äôs role is limited to holding and managing the assets until they are legally transferred to the rightful heirs.According to ET, the nominee cannot sell, trade, or make any transactional decisions about the assets.The account or policy owner can appoint anyone ‚Äî family, friends, or acquaintances ‚Äî as a nominee, though financial institutions often prefer close family members.In some cases, the nominee and the legal heir can be the same person, which helps in ensuring a smoother transfer of assets.The legal heir or beneficiary is the rightful owner of the assets once the original holder passes away.To claim ownership, the legal heir must produce valid documents such as a will or other testamentary proof.If there is no will ‚Äî a situation known as dying intestate ‚Äî the heir is determined as per the country‚Äôs succession or personal laws, reported ET.While a nominee can initially access the assets, only the legal heir can claim them permanently or challenge ownership in court.Experts quoted by ET emphasise that having clarity on this difference helps avoid disputes and ensures that the savings reach the intended family members or beneficiaries.Therefore, it is advisable to regularly update both nominees and wills to align with one‚Äôs estate planning goals.

Every year, lakhs of pensioners across India must prove that they are still alive to continue receiving their pension. Pensioners can now submit their certificates digitally from the comfort of their homes using Jeevan Pramaan, a secure, user-friendly, and Aadhaar-based platform.A Life Certificate is an official document that confirms a pensioner is alive. Without it, pension payments are automatically paused by the pension disbursing agency. This verification is essential for preventing fraudulent claims and ensuring that pensions reach the rightful beneficiaries.The Digital Life Certificate (DLC), also known as Jeevan Pramaan, is an advanced biometric-enabled version of the traditional paper certificate.Introduced by the Government of India, it uses Aadhaar-based biometric authentication using either fingerprint or iris scan to verify a pensioner‚Äôs identity. Once verified, a digital certificate is automatically generated and shared with authorised pension disbursing agencies.This online process eliminates the need for physical verification, providing elderly pensioners with a simpler and more accessible way to maintain their pension benefits.According to PIB, The submission of the Life Certificate is mandatory for all pensioners who wish to continue receiving their pension without interruption. During registration, the user provides their Aadhaar number and mobile number, after which an OTP (One-Time Password) is sent to their mobile. The system also asks whether the pensioner has remarried or is re-employed.After entering all details, the pensioner scans their fingerprint or iris using the registered biometric device. Upon successful authentication, the Digital Life Certificate is generated, and an SMS acknowledgment with the Jeevan Pramaan Certificate ID is sent to the registered mobile number.This certificate is automatically stored in the Life Certificate Repository, accessible anytime to both pensioners and pension agencies.Once the Digital Life Certificate is created, it can be electronically delivered to the concerned Pension Disbursing Agency (PDA). PDAs can log in to the Jeevan Pramaan portal to view, verify, or download the certificate directly.Pensioners can also download a PDF copy of their certificate by visiting the Jeevan Pramaan website and entering their Pramaan ID or Aadhaar number. This ensures transparency and easy access for future reference.The government provides several options to submit the Life Certificate, allowing pensioners to choose the method that suits them best.Pensioners who prefer traditional methods can visit their bank branch or a Citizen Service Centre (CSC) to submit their Life Certificate physically. Trained staff at these centres assist pensioners in verifying their details and completing the process.For those unable to travel due to age or health issues, India Post Payments Bank (IPPB) offers a doorstep banking service. Pensioners can schedule an appointment, and an IPPB representative will visit their home to complete the submission using biometric authentication. By visiting https://jeevanpramaan.gov.in, pensioners can submit their Digital Life Certificate using a computer, laptop, or smartphone equipped with a fingerprint or iris scanner.The system uses the Aadhaar platform to authenticate biometric details. Once verification is successful, a Digital Life Certificate is generated and stored in a secure online repository. Key components of hallmark on gold jewellery



Gold, silver hallmarking : Gold and silver jewllery have long been treasured for their beauty and value. However, ensuring their purity and authenticity is important, especially in a market prone to fraudulent practices. This is where the hallmarking scheme comes into play. Here‚Äôs what you need to know about hallmarking charges and its procedures:Hallmarking is the process of accurately determining and officially recording the proportionate content of precious metals in articles, such as gold and silver.It serves as a guarantee of their purity or fineness. In India, hallmarking is governed by stringent standards outlined in IS 15820, according to an ET report.Hallmarking charges are applied per article, regardless of its weight. For gold articles, the charge is Rs 45 per article, with a minimum charge of Rs 200 for a consignment. Similarly, for silver articles, the charge is Rs 35 per article, with a minimum charge of Rs 150 for a consignment. It's important to note that additional taxes and levies may apply.A consignment refers to a collection of articles with the same fineness, from which a sample is drawn and assayed for compliance. Different lots may exist within a consignment.Anyone can have their hallmarked jewellery tested for purity at an A&H centre by paying a testing fee of Rs. 200 (for testing using the fire assay method as per IS 1418). These centres must be recognized by the BIS. The list of recognized A&H centres is available on the BIS website under the hallmarking section.The primary objective of hallmarking is to safeguard consumers from counterfeit products. To achieve this, the Indian government made hallmarking mandatory for gold jewellery from June 16, 2021. Since April 1, 2023, jewellers are prohibited from selling any gold jewellery without a 6-digit Hallmark Unique Identification ( HUID ) number.If you bought gold jewellery on or before June 30, 2021, it may have old hallmarking signs. These signs include the purity/fineness mark and the BIS emblem, along with two additional indications: the jeweller's identification number and the assay centre's mark/number.However, starting July 1, 2021, these two indications were replaced with a unique alphanumeric HUID code. The hallmark remains valid for the lifetime of the jewellery, and consumers can sell old jewellery, whether hallmarked or un-hallmarked, to jewellers.The HUID, or hallmark Unique Identification number, is a key component of hallmarking in gold jewellery. It's a unique six-digit alphanumeric code assigned to each hallmarked item, allowing for traceability. Customers can verify the HUID number using the 'Verify HUID' feature in the BIS Care App.Since the introduction of the HUID on July 1, 2021, the hallmark on gold jewellery consists of three marks: the BIS logo, the purity of the article in caratage and fineness, and a unique six-digit alphanumeric HUID number.
